trans-unit.source: Credential assets in Azure Automation | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Credential assets in Azure Automation | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Credential assets in Azure Automation contain security credentials that can be used to authenticate to resources accessed by the runbook. This article describes how to create credential assets and use them in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: Credential assets in Azure Automation contain security credentials that can be used to authenticate to resources accessed by the runbook. This article describes how to create credential assets and use them in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: An Automation credential asset holds a <linkText>PSCredential</linkText><title></title> object which contains security credentials such as a username and password.
trans-unit.target: An Automation credential asset holds a <linkText>PSCredential</linkText><title></title> object which contains security credentials such as a username and password.

trans-unit.source: Runbooks may use cmdlets that accept a PSCredential object for authentication, or the runbook may extract the username and password of the PSCredential object to provide to some application or service requiring authentication.
trans-unit.target: Runbooks may use cmdlets that accept a PSCredential object for authentication, or the runbook may extract the username and password of the PSCredential object to provide to some application or service requiring authentication.

trans-unit.source: The properties for a credential are stored securely in Azure Automation and can be accessed in the runbook with the <linkText>Get-AutomationPSCredential</linkText><title></title> activity.
trans-unit.target: The properties for a credential are stored securely in Azure Automation and can be accessed in the runbook with the <linkText>Get-AutomationPSCredential</linkText><title></title> activity.

trans-unit.source: Secure assets in Azure Automation include credentials, certificates, connections, and encrypted variables.
trans-unit.target: Secure assets in Azure Automation include credentials, certificates, connections, and encrypted variables.

trans-unit.source: These assets are encrypted and stored in the Azure Automation using a unique key that is generated for each automation account.
trans-unit.target: These assets are encrypted and stored in the Azure Automation using a unique key that is generated for each automation account.

trans-unit.source: This key is encrypted by a master certificate and stored in Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: This key is encrypted by a master certificate and stored in Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: Before storing a secure asset, the key for the automation account is decrypted using the master certificate and then used to encrypt the asset.
trans-unit.target: Before storing a secure asset, the key for the automation account is decrypted using the master certificate and then used to encrypt the asset.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlets in the following table are used to create and manage automation credential assets with Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlets in the following table are used to create and manage automation credential assets with Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: They ship as part of the <linkText>Azure PowerShell module</linkText><title></title> which is available for use in Automation runbooks.
trans-unit.target: They ship as part of the <linkText>Azure PowerShell module</linkText><title></title> which is available for use in Automation runbooks.

trans-unit.source: Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationCredential</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get-AzureAutomationCredential</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Retrieves information about a credential asset.
trans-unit.target: Retrieves information about a credential asset.

trans-unit.source: You can only retrieve the credential itself from Get-AutomationCredential activity.
trans-unit.target: You can only retrieve the credential itself from Get-AutomationCredential activity.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New-AzureAutomationCredential</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New-AzureAutomationCredential</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Creates a new Automation credential.
trans-unit.target: Creates a new Automation credential.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Remove- AzureAutomationCredential</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Remove- AzureAutomationCredential</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Removes an Automation credential.
trans-unit.target: Removes an Automation credential.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set- AzureAutomationCredential</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set- AzureAutomationCredential</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Sets the properties for an existing Automation credential.
trans-unit.target: Sets the properties for an existing Automation credential.

trans-unit.source: The activities in the following table are used to access credentials in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: The activities in the following table are used to access credentials in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: Activities
trans-unit.target: Activities

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Get-AutomationPSCredential
trans-unit.target: Get-AutomationPSCredential

trans-unit.source: Gets a credential to use in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: Gets a credential to use in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: Returns a <linkText>System.Management.Automation.PSCredential</linkText><title></title> object.
trans-unit.target: Returns a <linkText>System.Management.Automation.PSCredential</linkText><title></title> object.

trans-unit.source: You should avoid using variables in the –Name parameter of Get-AutomationPSCredential since this can complicate discovering dependencies between runbooks and credential assets at design time.
trans-unit.target: You should avoid using variables in the –Name parameter of Get-AutomationPSCredential since this can complicate discovering dependencies between runbooks and credential assets at design time.

trans-unit.source: From your automation account, click Assets at the top of the window.
trans-unit.target: From your automation account, click Assets at the top of the window.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the window, click Add Setting.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the window, click Add Setting.

trans-unit.source: Click Add Credential.
trans-unit.target: Click Add Credential.

trans-unit.source: In the Credential Type dropdown, select PowerShell Credential.
trans-unit.target: In the Credential Type dropdown, select PowerShell Credential.

trans-unit.source: Complete the wizard and click the checkbox to save the new credential.
trans-unit.target: Complete the wizard and click the checkbox to save the new credential.

trans-unit.source: From your automation account, click the Assets part to open the Assets blade.
trans-unit.target: From your automation account, click the Assets part to open the Assets blade.

trans-unit.source: Click the Credentials part to open the Credentials blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Credentials part to open the Credentials blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Add a credential at the top of the blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Add a credential at the top of the blade.

trans-unit.source: Complete the form and click Create to save the new credential.
trans-unit.target: Complete the form and click Create to save the new credential.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to create a new automation credential.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to create a new automation credential.

trans-unit.source: A PSCredential object is first created with the name and password and then used to create the credential asset.
trans-unit.target: A PSCredential object is first created with the name and password and then used to create the credential asset.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you could use the Get-Credential cmdlet to be prompted to type in a name and password.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you could use the Get-Credential cmdlet to be prompted to type in a name and password.

trans-unit.source: You retrieve a credential asset in a runbook with the Get-AutomationPSCredential activity.
trans-unit.target: You retrieve a credential asset in a runbook with the Get-AutomationPSCredential activity.

trans-unit.source: This returns a <linkText>PSCredential object</linkText><title></title> that you can use with an activity or cmdlet that requires a PSCredential parameter.
trans-unit.target: This returns a <linkText>PSCredential object</linkText><title></title> that you can use with an activity or cmdlet that requires a PSCredential parameter.

trans-unit.source: You can also retrieve the properties of the credential object to use individually.
trans-unit.target: You can also retrieve the properties of the credential object to use individually.

trans-unit.source: The object has a property for the username and the secure password, or you can use the GetNetworkCredential method to return a NetworkCredential object that will provide an unsecured version of the password.
trans-unit.target: The object has a property for the username and the secure password, or you can use the GetNetworkCredential method to return a NetworkCredential object that will provide an unsecured version of the password.

trans-unit.source: The following sample commands show how to use a PowerShell credential in a runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following sample commands show how to use a PowerShell credential in a runbook.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the credential is retrieved and its username and password assigned to variables.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the credential is retrieved and its username and password assigned to variables.

trans-unit.source: You add a Get-AutomationPSCredential activity to a graphical runbook by right-clicking on the credential in the Library pane of the graphical editor and selecting Add to canvas.
trans-unit.target: You add a Get-AutomationPSCredential activity to a graphical runbook by right-clicking on the credential in the Library pane of the graphical editor and selecting Add to canvas.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add credential to canvas</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add credential to canvas</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The following image shows an example of using a credential in a graphical runbook.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows an example of using a credential in a graphical runbook.

trans-unit.source: In this case, it is being used to provide authentication for a runbook to Azure resources as described in <linkText>Configuring authentication to Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In this case, it is being used to provide authentication for a runbook to Azure resources as described in <linkText>Configuring authentication to Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The first activity retrieves the credential that has access to the Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The first activity retrieves the credential that has access to the Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: The Add-AzureAccount activity then uses this credential to provide authentication for any activities that come after it.
trans-unit.target: The Add-AzureAccount activity then uses this credential to provide authentication for any activities that come after it.

trans-unit.source: A pipeline link is here since Get-AutomationPSCredential is expecting a single object.
trans-unit.target: A pipeline link is here since Get-AutomationPSCredential is expecting a single object.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add credential to canvas</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add credential to canvas</linkText>
